Award.AwardTitle: GIS Certificate and Program Emphasis at South Central College

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is creating a GIS Certificate Program that is related to an existing Civil Engineering Technology (CET) program by creating two new courses, providing new necessary instrumentation relevant to the project, creating a 2+2+2 articulation agreement with area schools and regional universities, conducting faculty development activities, and implementing outreach activities. Various state, county and city government employees as well as numerous independent consulting engineers increasingly use GIS as a tool for planning, design, data management, and utility location. The GIS Certificate Program is providing current CET students with GIS skills that they are using in conjunction with their CET degree upon entering the workforce. The project is also providing regional CET employees with additional learning opportunities that are expanding and enhancing their existing GIS skills. The GIS Certificate Program design is being guided by an advisory board composed of local industry employers, many of whom are also participating in the new Practicum course developed through this project, and the ATE GeoTech Center. The resultant hands-on Certificate Program is providing students with opportunities to apply their GIS skills to various civil engineering applications, including infrastructure management (storm, sanitary, water), corridor studies, environmental studies, traffic analysis, and land management activities. Students enrolled in newly developed courses of the Certificate Program are expected to demonstrate proficiency with GIS hardware and software, and also demonstrate spatial data communication, spatial analysis, and data delivery skills. Student learning is being assessed through the use of rubrics, testing and performance evaluations, and peer review. Formative evaluation is guiding ongoing improvements in the program. The project is also developing articulation agreements with regional universities that are allowing CET students who earn the GIS certificate to continue their studies towards 4-year GIS degrees. In addition, a GIS training camp is providing training on the use of GIS to faculty and staff from CET, agriculture, marketing, and geography who have demonstrated interest towards incorporating GIS into their existing courses and curricula. Finally, the project is providing GIS-based summer camps for K-12 students in order to enhance their interest in pursuing STEM careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
South Central College, a community and technical college located in North Mankato, MN acquired a Program Emphasis Advance Technology Education grant funded by the National Science Foundation to develop a Geographic Information System (GIS) certificate. This included developing two new GIS courses, Field Mapping with GPS, and GIS Practicum, as well as creating
a GIS lab consisting of GPS equipment to collect field data, and GIS and CAD software to manipulate the data.  The lab is utilized by both the Civil Engineering Technology and GIS programs, as well as other programs within the college. Additional objectives of this project were to support partnerships with city, county, state, and private engineering agencies and educational institutes; reach out to diverse populations through the implementation of career pathways  and outreach activities (focused on recruiting underrepresented populations); and build the Civil Engineering Technology program’s capacity by receiving and offering professional development initiatives to current industry employees.

 

A unique educational delivery model was used to deliver the GIS courses.  Students were partnered with agencies that needed specific tasks or projects completed using GIS technology. SCC’s GIS instructors then developed and managed specific projects for students to work on in cooperation with these partners. In addition, the instructors provided guidance and expertise to the partnering agencies in regards to project workflow.  As each project was unique, students received individualized instruction related to their project. This also provided students with the opportunity to develop their critical thinking skills by solving problems that occur regularly when working on projects of this nature; for example, troubleshooting software/hardware issues and project work flow and resource management. These partnership projects have proven successful for both the students and the partnering agencies.

 

The primary projects students worked on were developing specialized geographic information systems for partners, such as infrastructure inventories of storm, sanitary and water systems; signal and lighting systems; land use and county planning systems; farm drainage systems; and environmental mapping evaluations. Students collected field data using a mapping grade GPS (Global Positioning System), downloaded the information to a computer system, and developed GIS and CAD (Computer Aided Design)  maps and database inventories. This information was then given to the partnering agencies for them to use for their various business decisions.


Additionally, GIS instructors developed curriculum geared toward junior high students, and summer camps were offered to these students in the hopes of sparking their interest in seeking a higher education STEM (science, math, technology and engineering) degree.

 

South Central College is committed to continuing the project-based learning model used in the GIS certificate program with partnerships developed during the grant period. We also hope to develop additional partnerships for the future.
